commentBody:
Fun puzzle!  I knew the theme right away when I saw 18A, and even knew the film off the top of my head--I had bought Ebert's collection "I Hated, Hated, Hated This Movie" at a train station back in the 2000s.

My only criticism is that it would have been nice to celebrate both Siskel and Ebert, since I believe this week marks the 50th anniversary of their debut as a reviewer team on television.
A nice Wednesday offering with snappy answers!
I went for a long time being sure )I mean REALLY sure) that an Amazon wrapper was a box.
As a kid, I rented and actually liked North. Haha

Two thumbs up for me. I so miss Roger Ebert. I did wonder as I was reading the clues whether these were movie critiques or quotes from crossword commentators. 

Pretty straightforward clues‚Äîmaybe more a Tuesday? Nothing too tricky, except ‚ÄúAmazon wrapper‚Äù which gave me a smile. One comment, I never noticed signs at school zones that say SLO instead of ‚ÄúSlow‚Äù. If so it‚Äôs pretty ironic that we can‚Äôt even teach our kids to spell in a school zone.
Lyle Lovett held the key to 52A with his album ‚ÄúJoshua Judges Ruth.‚Äù

It must be a curious mix of achievement and slight to learn one has written a "ditty." On one hand, the term implies something lesser. On the other hand, they do make quite a nest for themselves in the brain, don't they?

So then, I wanna know. What's your favourite ditty?

Congratulations on the debut! Movies are usually right up my alley - I didn't know any of these by the review right off the top of my head, but the crosses made pretty quick work of them, which led to a nice breezy solve. Not a personal best, but only about a minute off. Very enjoyable!

The inclusion of an Oscar Wilde quote (23A) is a fun addition. If he had been around a hundred years later, I bet he‚Äôd have put out some doozies of hilarious dismissive movie reviews.
‚ÄúConsistency is the last refuge of the unimaginative  - I really really really hated this movie.‚Äù

Felt fairly breezy for a Wednesday.  I loved Roger Ebert, and suspected he was the theme pretty early on.  

My one, minor quibble is the clue for 10A.  My entire backyard is a hill of moss, and it grows on all sides of all the trees.  The idea that it only grows on the north side of trees is a myth.  It grows where it's shady, cool, and damp.

Quite an enjoyable debut, Mr. McClung. I think that‚Äôs it was matched with the correct day of the week, which is always good.

I think I would recognize Roger Ebert‚Äôs writing almost anywhere. During the last chapter of his life he was producing op-eds on important societal issues related to both Chicago and the nation, in addition to his movie reviews. He was an irreplaceable treasure and is dearly missed.
Great theme, fun cluing, congrats on the successful debut!

I loved how ‚Äúauteur‚Äù was thrown in with Ebert‚Äôs hilarious pans of Hollywood schlock.  

There was a bit of a missed opportunity to clue ‚Äústone‚Äù as director Oliver Stone, but I‚Äôm nitpicking. 

Great theme, good fill - more like this, please!
"Fifteen minutes of fun packed into thirty-one minutes!"

As soon as I hit the first movie review clue, I jumped down to the revealer to see if ROGER EBERT fit.  Spoiler Alert. It did. The movies needed a few letters to fill in, except BATTLEFIELD EARTH.  Knew that one. Had BrA before BOA for Amazon wrap because I was thinking woman warrior rather than snake. D'oh.
Pretty niche puzzle, fortunately for me my niche. I won't be surprised if non-Americans, youngsters and non-movie watchers are unhappy.

I suspected it was Ebertisms early on, but oddly the first movie I nailed was ARMAGEDDON which contrary to his opinion I enjoyed. I do agree with him on the rest though. Wanted rear for HIND/BUTT early on. On a side note I find Ness stacked on North interesting, thinking of gangsters and Oliver North‚Ä¶ hmm maybe I just dated myself. Also had CNN before MTV. Nice Wednesday debut

I really, really enjoyed this puzzle.  

I go way back to "Sneak Preview" on PBS with Siskel and Ebert.  I loved that show, loved their success (tragically short in Siskel's case) but I also missed their outgrowing their PBS origins.  What a success story!  And there is a lot of hilarious literature about pranks they played on one another--I think it's pretty clear that they weren't exactly bosom buddies.

Ebert's five-fold repetition of "hated" in his North review is something I've used numerous times for things I despised.  What a happy surprise to see it in the crossword puzzle.

Now, that doesn't mean I glided to a perfect landing.  I plucked around for quite a while fixing an embarrassment of errors.  Not nED, but JED.  Not LAUREl but LAUREN.  Not IPoD, but IPAD (which was tough with the cross, that could go "a" or "o".)

And every time I found one of these I was overcome with relief, only to be shattered when all I got was another "Sorry". 

And each time, I could feel a tiny but vital bit of life force draining from me...that was dumb.  I just felt annoyed.

I think my problem is that I consider doing the puzzle as the price of admission to the comments.  I've never read the comments before closing a puzzle.  

So that puts an extra urgency on solving the puzzle.  It's how I get to the party.

I'm surprised to find that I'm still writing this.  I'd be even more surprised if you're still reading this.
I await the day that the answer for 37D will be clued "Tennis star Fonseca"
Really phenomenal debut. Made me laugh, snicker, and go read more of Ebert's reviews. Looking forward to more from this constructor!

This was my quickest solve this week, and faster than my Tuesday average, even though I was unfamiliar with the guy, and the rather unfunny, unoriginal and generic quotes were very little help in identifying the specific movies. The clueing may have possibly been toughened up a bit for Wednesday?

My wife and I spent the night in Drumnadrochit on our Scottish trip several years ago. I actually remembered the name today, and the way our host pronounced it. The local pub served good food, and the aptly named beer HoppyNess.

I'll post my 2020 review of "Inception" in a reply - it will take some creative editing to get it past the emus...

getting stumped for a bit by the clever final fill for amazon wrapper after receiving no love from the juan:spanish cross (gotta be joan like joan miro - i KNOW hes not portuguese but it wont go away) made the entire 14 minutes worth it.

Found this very easy for Wednesday, but I had an advantage in that I used to read Ebert reviews on Compuserve as a little kid in 1994, it seemed like the next best thing to actually seeing those movies. I remember North had just come out and so his review was featured, and it was a pretty entertaining read.

Roger Ebert, Oscar Wilde, Nathaniel Hawthorne‚Äîwhat‚Äôs not to love about the puzzle? 

I needed a few crosses before ARMAGEDDON popped in, and I couldn‚Äôt quite remember the movie. So, later, I googled it, and went, ‚ÄúAhhh, yes.‚Äù I had just finished misspending my youth as a physics undergrad when the movie came out, and I was on a date with a guy from my department when I saw it. We laughed ourselves silly. Aptly, too, Wikipedia quotes Ben Affleck as saying, "I asked [director] Michael why it was easier to train oil drillers to become astronauts than it was to train astronauts to become oil drillers, and he told me to shut the [hi, emus] up, so that was the end of that talk."

Ebert called ‚Äòem as he saw ‚Äòem. A talent to be forever missed. 

Nice job on your debut, John. I‚Äôm still smiling at the BOA clue.

Share your most loved/hated films today in honor of Roger Ebert and this puzzle! Also I need some good recs.

Loved - Casablanca
Hated - LOTR

One of my favorite critics was Tom Shales, who wrote for many years at The Washington Post (and received the Pulitzer Prize for Criticism for his work at the Post).  Per Wikipedia, ‚ÄúShales was known for his withering putdowns of shows he disliked, and was nicknamed ‚ÄòTerrible Tom‚Äô and ‚ÄòThe Terror of the Tube‚Äô.‚Äù  I recall hearing his reviews on NPR‚Äôs Morning Edition in the late 1990s as I commuted to work.  He was also a guest co-host on ‚ÄúRoger Ebert & the Movies‚Äù after Gene Siskel passed away.
IFEAR I had you ‚Äúate‚Äù  at 56D for the longest, ALAS the tRUTH is I still FEEl this puzzle was a PEARL!

As a big fan of Roger Ebert back in the day, I love love loved this puzzle. He called ‚Äòem as he seen ‚Äòem, and even when he was scathing he was always fair. 

I used to follow his Movie Answer Man column on Compuserve.(And if that doesn‚Äôt date me, nothing will!) One day, I wrote him an email to offer a counter opinion to something he had written, and much to my surprise, he replied with a lengthy, thoughtful and appreciative response. He was a true gentleman, and movie criticism hasn‚Äôt been the same without him.

Two thumbs up. (Gene, I miss you, too.)

Congratulations on your debut, John, and thank you for a well-made puzzle, fun to work, and I'm always glad to spend some time with an old friend.   At least we felt Roger Ebert was an old friend from the time he showed up with Gene Siskel on PBS.  I tended to side more with Siskel than Ebert, but after Siskel died (way too young), I was still devoted to the show and always eager to hear Ebert's take on new movies. I google his reviews now when we're trying to decide on whether an older movie will be worth watching, and I still disagree with his take sometimes, but that just adds to the pleasure of reading his reviews.

Fun puzzle (loved "Amazon wrapper"), but I couldn't help being bothered by 2-Down. The term IGUANA generally refers to a group of lizard species, with the marine iguana (Amblyrhynchus cristatus) being one of those species, not a subspecies.

Great movie-themed puzzle today. Was a fan of Mr Ebert too.

IFEAR had me in a chokehold for far too long. Not unsurprising considering it crossed with BOA.

How the fans (IMDb rating; out of 10) and other critics (Metascore; out of 100) ranked these movies:

Armageddon: 6.7 / 42

Pearl Harbor: 6.3 / 44

North: 4.6 / 33

Battlefield Earth: 2.5 / 9
Never heard of Roger Ebert or the movies so puzzle a waste of space for me. Trivia in the theme never good.

This was a fun puzzle! I knew it had to be Roger Ebert before I got to the revealer. I was able to get all of the movies with the crossings. I loved BOA as the answer for ‚ÄúAmazon wrapper‚Äù. Thanks, John! Have a wonderful Wednesday, y‚Äôall!

I did fill in the correct one first, but TIL ROGEREBERT has the same number of letters as Gene Siskel, even a common ‚ÄúE‚Äù in the fourth position. I used to watch Siskel and Ebert regularly and feel like that knowledge would have annoyed them mightily. üëç
I really enjoyed NORTH! Never quite understood the hate. It's got Bruce Willis in a bunny suit, what's not to love?

I hadn't heard of ROGER EBERT, and haven't seen any of the films. However, I solved all the clues with the crossers, as they were mostly simple synonyms or general knowledge. I only needed help with ORTEGA - I haven't seen Beetlejuice either!

The theme obviously evokes such fond memories for many, which I can't share, and fair enough. Clive James is a critic I remember similarly. 

Otherwise, quite straightforward.

I'm not much of a movie goer, but I enjoyed this. Everything was gettable with crosses and it took longer for me than recent early week puzzles, and I always like that. Not about movies, but my all-time favorite restaurant review: https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/14/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-guys-american-kitchen-bar-in-times-square.html?unlocked_article_code=1.4E8.X7rK.xj9PD9d832mA&smid=url-share
Pleasure . Send more John
I loved this puzzle. Loved loved loved loved loved this puzzle. Loved it.
I didn't want it to end!

I love Roger Ebert's reviews and it was the first name I thought of when I read the revealer clue! Fun clues for the films, reminding me of some "so bad they're good" experiences :)
Armageddon, for example, he's right that it just makes zero sense from start to finish, but somehow I've watched it many times!
There's a great "Cinema Sins" YouTube video about it as well, with a lovely part where they show the two spaceships (the "Freedom" and the "Independence") being prepared to lift off, and the crews are told "Freedom crew, this way! Indpendence crew, this way" and the comment: "neither the Freedom crew nor the Independence crew are allowed to decide which way to go."
Thanks, John!
Roger Ebert was the best.
I loved every square of this.
Really clever theme! I don't often enjoy a Wednesday puzzle, but this one was a treat!

Do Amazons wear boas? When, at first, I had B_A, I assumed "bra," which was no more likely, although the Amazon Queen Hyppolyte was famous for her girdle. But boas? Well, "Amazon" can have quite a few meanings, none of which involve the wearing of boas--although I have known a few imposing drag queens who might be described as amazon-like. Even though she never gets to wear a boas, Here she comes, Miss Amphipolis: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=102krAbCJ1Q "Remember, a beauty pageant is like a war . . . " *** *** In more recent times, my favorite movie reviews have been written for the New Yorker by Anthony Lane, who, alas, has retired from that beat (but not the publication entirely). His reviews of *Mother!* (which was one of my friend Tom's favorite movies), and the most recent adaptation of *The Call of the Wild* were particularly memorable. *** *** This was a great puzzle, Mr. McClung!

Also from Roger Ebert:

To call ‚ÄúA Lot Like Love‚Äù dead in the water is an insult to water. (2005)

On the movie ‚ÄúMr. Magoo‚Äù:  There is not a laugh in it.  Not one.  I counted.  (1997)

On the movie ‚ÄúMasterminds‚Äù:  I stopped taking notes on my Palm Pilot and started playing the little chess game.  (1997)

You may know this one already, but my favorite Roger Ebert story isn't about the movies. He was watching a movie one night, decided it was a waste of his time, and wandered into a folk club that was having an open mic night. Knowing nothing about the performer, he happened upon a mailman who was playing guitar and singing his own compositions. Yes, that is how the world learned about John Prine. https://www.rogerebert.com/features/john-prine-american-legend

A very enjoyable puzzle today.

I had never heard of Roger Ebert but his reviews made me laugh out loud, especially the Pearl Harbor one. What a wit!

I guess there must have been some movies he did like? ü§î

A fine tribute debut with some very witty clues.  Congrats. 

Looking at the column's photo and I can't make out what the fellow is holding.  A camera?
A fun puzzle. I even enjoyed the typing scenes.
Loved this one. So much fun!

The only movie I'd ever heard of was Armageddon. Nevertheless, it was pretty easy to complete the puzzle and figure out that it was Roger Ebert whose reviews were quoted.

But the happy coincidence for me was the answer to 38A. For days now I've been wracking my brain trying to remember the name of a phenomenal indie movie, likely the very first indie movie, I saw in the early mid-80s, and NORTH made it pop into my brain. The movie was El Norte, and few here have probably ever heard of or seen it. I urge you to either find it online or at least to read the Wikipedia article about it. It is so poignantly and heartbreakingly apropos of what is going on today, but also interspersed with a bit of comical relief. Roger Ebert is even quoted in the article, and Wikipedia cites the one scene I remember best, when the heroine is exposed to the modern convenience of a washing machine.

El Norte received an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay in 1985. In 1995, the film was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant". I hope that the current thugs in charge of destroying our culture don't rip this film from its place in the LOC.

Much to trigger smiles today:
‚Ä¢	The Ebert barbs, each of which brought s genuine ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù
‚Ä¢	Words/phrases I greatly enjoy: DITTIES, AUTEURS, HOBNOB, BENDERS, BUM RAP.  
‚Ä¢	TOM on Thanksgiving Eve.
‚Ä¢	The constructor‚Äôs notes, with more Ebert digs and the line ‚Äúthe monkey who lives in my cranium‚Äù.
‚Ä¢	A rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap REPEL.
‚Ä¢	MAE crossing EAST, causing my brain to tap me on the shoulder and shout, ‚ÄúMAE should have crossed WEST!‚Äù
‚Ä¢	Speaking of directions, NORTH crossing NOTRE, which anagrams to ‚Äúnorte‚Äù, Spanish for NORTH.
‚Ä¢	The inspiring backstory of the constructor, who today had a puzzle published in the NYT, one year after he started making them.  Wow!

Congratulations, John.  What a terrific tribute puzzle ‚Äì thank you!
PERFECT for today!! Wrestling with the turkey is enough of a challenge. This was fun. Gobble, gobble everyone! üòã

Some puzzles are a workout, which I love.

Some are a puzzle-in-a-puzzle, which I love.

Some are a riddle, some a play on words.
Love ‚Äòem.

Today‚Äôs was a romp. A frolic.
The perfect song playing on the radio
as the weather has shifted and the windows are open 
and the world feels a bit lighter,
and you just want to keep on driving‚Ä¶

What a delightful puzzle theme!  Kudos and thanks to Mr. McClung for a wonderful debut, and for reminding us of how a well-placed (ahem!) barb can become the stuff of legend.

Somewhere up there, Dorothy Parker is smiling.

I‚Äôm surprised that the clue for 2D wasn‚Äôt tied more directly into the theme.

From Roger Ebert‚Äôs review of Godzilla (1998):
‚ÄúOh, and then there are New York‚Äôs Mayor Ebert (gamely played by Michael Lerner) and his adviser, Gene (Lorry Goldman). The mayor of course makes every possible wrong decision (he is against evacuating Manhattan, etc.), and the adviser eventually gives thumbs-down to his reelection campaign. These characters are a reaction by Emmerich and Devlin to negative Siskel and Ebert reviews of their earlier movies (‚ÄòStargate,‚Äô ‚ÄòIndependence Day‚Äô), but they let us off lightly; I fully expected to be squished like a bug by Godzilla.‚Äù

As "Ditty" is a word I use often in these comments, I feel compelled to offer a couple for your amusement (the second a little better-known than the first): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvTtzUyyeIA&list=RDqvTtzUyyeIA&start_radio=1 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h04CH9YZcpI&list=RDh04CH9YZcpI&start_radio=1 And pertaining more to the clue for 25A than the answer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4a4naYEHUZs&list=RD4a4naYEHUZs&start_radio=1

With a nod to 6D. TERRIF!
It took me awhile to get going. NW corner finally came together at the end. Only needed Google to verify my guesses and nail down actor names.

Enjoyable puzzle. As a combat veteran and - having a father-in-law who was at Pearl Harbor - early on I thought this was an entirely different theme. Yeah - until I got to the reveal. No big deal. Most of it filled in fairly smoothly, and then it was just working the crosses elsewhere. 

A pair of puzzle finds today - kind of interesting. A Monday from October 22, 1979 and a Thursday from January 2, 1986. In the Monday puzzle the three theme answers were: 

EMERALDISLE
THEDIAMONDSTATE
PEARLHARBOR

In the Thursday puzzle: 

EMERALDCITY
DIAMONDHEAD
EMERALDISLE
PEARLHARBOR

Just hadn't stumbled across such a similar pair of puzzles before. 

....
I liked this puzzle a lot, John. Well done, and thank you for the reminder of what a good (and clever) review of a movie could be when delivered by the witty Evert.

What a magnificent debut! While I did find it fairly easy to solve (nearly 8 minutes off my average time), I was truly delighted to re-read many of Ebert‚Äôs reviews both in the puzzle and in the constructor‚Äôs notes. And the link in Sam‚Äôs column to the Mandela effect had me wondering how many other things I have missed-remembered!

"Amazon wrapper." Nice one, John!

Boa vs. anaconda--who wins?

Wonderful puzzle and very entertaining constructor notes. Great debut, John McClung! Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel did the unthinkable by delivering movie reviews that made good TV. If not for them we might never have had the hilarious parody called Men on Film featuring Damon Wayons and David Alan Grier on In Living Color. Two snaps up!

Poor Michael Bay taking a one-two punch in this puzzle.

That said, I saw Armageddon when I was 13 and it's still an unabashed favorite 27 years later (good lord).

What a fun, snappy puzzle! (Amazon wrapper?? MWAH!!) 

I'd never noticed how many four-letter synonyms for "posterior" there are (seat, rear, rump ...)

And those Ebert quotes were just glorious. Thank you, John - please may we have some more?
I typically  don't read movie reviews but not want to read the ones done by Ebert!

Critic who wrote: "I guess I have an incredible nose for schlock, because not only didn't I see any of these movies -- I  wasn't even aware that they were movies." (2025)
                                                 --Nancy

Loved this puzzle anyway.  Ebert's reviews are SO funny that it almost doesn't matter if you don't know what movie he's talking about.  I used to watch him on the TV show "Siskel and Ebert" and I don't remember him being all that acerbic.  The critic whom I remember as acerbic is John Simon.  Dorothy Parker too, though I'm not old enough to have actually read her reviews contemporaneously.

Happy Thanksgiving, everyone.
I'm not a movie person in the least, but your tight construction got me through it. Thanks for a great puzzle!

My mother wants to make sure everyone knows that Roger Ebert is from Urbana, IL, and attended our alma mater, the University of Illinois. 

Growing up, he was somewhat of a local hero, so the theme was easy for me to figure out, even if the movies weren‚Äôt always obvious. I dearly wish Deuce Bigelow had made the puzzle!

I felt like I was on one of those treasure hunts where you got sent hither, thither, and yon seeking clues to the next stop on an interminable quest!  
But with a few laughs along the way, thank goodness.

I thought (briefly) that I was learning a new word...AUTEARS?
...but it was a BAD RAP....and then a BUM (HIND, BUTT) one.

Query:  was 43A--the movie--longer than the actual attack on the HARBOR itself?  (Because Schofield Barracks, Wheeler AFB,  and Hickam Field were attacked after the flight came through Kolekole Pass on the way to Honolulu...)

Thanks for the laughs. That was a joyous grid. I don‚Äôt know Mr Ebert, but I completely agree with his review of the one film in that list I had seen, ARMAGEDDON. 
I love the word HOBNOB, it has such a robust, meaty sound. Also Hobnob chocolate biscuits, when I used to eat biscuits (step away from the tin Helen). Proper workman like snacks; thick, crunchy, chocolatey and can withstand a prolonged dunk in a cuppa. The SAS of the biscuit world. Damn. I really want a biscuit now.

Maybe my fastest Wednesday ever ‚Äî having a copy of "Your Movie Sucks" that I read cover-to-cover as a teen absolutely helped. I can remember those reviews like song lyrics. Thanks for a puzzle as witty, snarky, and fun as reading Roger Ebert himself always was!

Loved loved loved loved loved it! Especially as a connoisseur of bad movies. NORTH was a stinker, but it's got nothing on Mac and Me. Morgan Spurlock called it the "worst thing you'll ever see in your entire life"

Immediately knew the North clue.  I remember watching the New York Friars Club Roast of Rob Reiner on Comedy Central, and Richard Belzer asked him to come up on stage and read something... it was Ebert's review of North that started with I hated this movie. Hated hated hated hated...
"Amazon wrapper" üèÜ

Lots of respect to this and all constructors, and I‚Äôm glad some seemed to enjoy this puzzle! 

Personally‚Ä¶. What an absolute snooze and bummer of a theme. It wasn‚Äôt even a theme‚Ä¶. It was just some films that one particular critic said some things about. No word play, no clever connection between the film and the review, nothing. Really surprised that this was accepted to NYT.
Here‚Äôs a challenge (I think) for one of you geniuses out there: 11-7-2009. I found it impossible, but curious if it‚Äôs just me‚Ä¶

So I'll join in the exercise of remembering loved and hated movies.
Hated is easy: Hurt Locker. Don't Look Up
Loved is harder (to prioritize)
Casablanca
Little Miss Sunshine
Philadephia
Winter's Bone
Ida (@Andrzej have you seen it?)
The Reader
Schindler's List
  Last 3 do have a common subject.
This is now my favorite puzzle of the year. I give thanks John Mcclug for an enjoyable evening and now I have a list of films to watch over this long weekend. Cheers!
Congratulations on a fabulous first time construction, John!  The clueing was so clever and I also enjoyed reading your constructor notes -- I hope we see many more from you!

I watch a lot of movies but of the movies in this puzzle I've only seen Pearl Harbor or maybe part of Pearl Harbor, I'm not sure. I will have to check the others out. I've also never seen The Sopranos (mentioned as well in the puzzle) except for the first five minutes.

Here is a brief list of my most hated and favorites:

Most hated--Manchester By The Sea. Don't see this movie. If I was reviewing it, I would say that this movie shows what happens to women who stand up for their rights. Worst movie ever.

Here are some favs:

The Grifters
Billy Elliot
and of course, Carousel.
For fun, Jerry and Marge Go Large
This was a PR for me for Wednesday! I liked it :)

The movies that Ebert deems great are indeed great movies. But he trashed a lot of camp classics, doing them a disservice by failing to see how entertaining they are in their campiness. It‚Äôs like a food critic who doesn‚Äôt like sweets reviewing ice cream. ‚ÄúHey this isn‚Äôt food! It‚Äôs just cream and sugar!‚Äù
Armageddon was a generationally awesome movie. To heck with Ebert! Fun crossword; great job.

Does anyone else remember Joe Bob Briggs? He wrote amusing reviews of "drive-in" movies, i.e. those not made by auteurs. His ratings included number of dead bodies, number of bared bosoms, and characterizations of the fight scenes as "fu." There could be chain-fu, pool cue-fu, etc, and also an estimation of pints of blood spilled. Anyway, that was more my speed than Siskel & Ebert's "serious" criticism. I still enjoyed the puzzle, though...and we got JED Clampett a day after Buddy EPSEN.
SLO is SHI fill. The only blemish on an otherwise excellent debut.

Overall, I thought it was a fun crossword. I enjoyed the theme, even if I don‚Äôt really like anything Ebert has ever done. üòÇ 

I thought SLO was a lazy fill but other than that it was a great Wednesday puzzle!

Happy Thanksgiving everyone!!
I have long been a huge Roger Ebert fan and I knew some of these answers right off. Wonderful idea for a theme! Thanks!

I had IPoD crossed with Jenna ORTEGo. Took me like forever to find it. 
1000 lashes with a wet noodle!!
A great puzzle and theme! Today, incidentally, is the 50th Anniversary of the debut of Siskel & Ebert on public television. Great job, editors!
I was so certain "Amazon Wrapper" was a "bra." :(

I forgot to turn on autocheck for this puzzle and by the time I remembered I had enough fill that I thought I might be able to finish it with less help and just switched to pencil instead. It took a while, and a look up for 42A got me TiM instead of TOM, but once I got that fixed I had my first three-day streak in months. Actually, this puzzle was a lot easier than Monday's!

Always happy to have occasion to remember my favorite opening line to a Roger Ebert review:

‚ÄúPEARL HARBOR is a two hour movie squeezed into three hours how, on December 7, 1941, the Japanese launched a surprise attack on an American love triangle.‚Äù

BadRAP kept me from the jingle, and I had never heard of the channel dTV. Before that I had CNN. Finally, it sunk in: BUMRAP and MTV made much more sense. 

A much faster Wednesday for me than usual, which, in a day crammed with cooking, I truly appreciate. I'm trying mashed potatoes with Tahini this year, instead of dairy. We'll see how that goes. A tiny taste test goes first. Just in case.

Don't burn down your kitchens, folks, and here's hoping no one loses power this year! 

Tomorrow, let's hear what you're thankful for!

For anyone else who was having significant overheating issues recently with the Android NYT Games app, uninstalling then reinstalling seems to have fixed the issue, at least for me. 

(Before the reinstall, a 10 minute crossword was causing more battery drain and thermal issues for my new phone than 30 minutes of high graphics gaming).

This was a tough Wednesday but a fun one! Loved seeing those old reviews from ROGEREBERT - what is more fun to read than a well written pan? The NW corner was tough.  Finally made progress when I figured out OGOD, not ‚ÄúLord,‚Äù the logical guess. Finished when I figured out IPAD, not iPod. üôÇ

Well, that was fun. 

I see I wasn't the only one who had Bad before BUM. Although I knew those crosses couldn't be right, I forgot to go back and check them before filling in my last square, so didn't get the happy music on my first try. But the whole thing was a delight.
Today I'm thankful for my love of Lyle Lovett's album "Joshua Judges RUTH."

Apologies for my ignorance, but can someone help explain how streaks work for the crossword?  I had assumed that a gold star puzzle indicated a step in a streak (ie 12 stars in a row = streak of 12) but I‚Äôve noticed that this is not necessarily the case.  

For instance I recently achieved 9 gold stars in a row, but my streak was reported as 7.  Any ideas?

Great memories from "Siskel and Ebert".

Occasionally they would do "Guilty Pleasures", movies that were just flat out awful but they somehow liked.

Ebert once mentioned one guilty pleasure, a Japanese monster movie.  He quotes a line in the movie "Things are so bad now, they have never been worse before."  That is a classically and hilariously bad line.  Of course it was also a translation.

One final comment, concerning the rivalry between Siskel and Ebert.

The story goes that Ebert was on a plane, and a flight attendant told him the pilot knew he was aboard and would like him to visit him in the pilot's cabin.  So he went to the door and knocked, and was curtly  told to stop knocking and go back to his seat.

As he was going back, he saw a hysterically laughing Siskel sitting right behind him.

this is fantastic absolutely hilarious and spot on clues/answers
bravo John for a stellar debut!
this was super fun puzzle to solve on a wednesday and page proper homage to a former icon that ruled the roost so to speak when it came to film reviews.

Growing up in the 70s and 80s, I *loved* watching Siskel and Ebert. And long after Gene Siskel died and ROGER EBERT lost the ability to speak, I enjoyed reading Ebert's witty reviews. RIP to them both.

Re columnist Sam's note on 12D, I thought of SLO immediately. Might be a US-specific thing. It is a tad silly to shorten a four-letter word to three letters, but our country is known for far sillier things...

Two thumbs up for a great debut puzzle, Mr. McClung!  I especially enjoyed the clue, "People looking for hookups, informally,"  this one made me laugh hysterically.  I hope to see your name on a puzzle again soon.

Harsh words for Bourne movies, but they are far better than the books. Really high production standards, first class actors (Matt Damon, Franka Potenta, Julia Stiles, Brian Cox, Edward Norton, Rachel Weisz, Joan Allen, Clive Owen, Albert Finney, among many others), interesting plots, and thrilling action scenes that make Tom Cruise action movies seem like tedious crash/bash, repetitious video games, with hopelessly dumb plots.  

Don't write them off so easily until you've watched the first three (forget the last one).

This is my favorite NYT crossword that I've ever worked, and I do the puzzle every day. First, I adored Roger Ebert, and the reviews quoted in these clues made me laugh. Then, the clues are literate, not irritating chemicals or math allusions.  And, other than the Ebert quotes, only two clues reference trivia -- not terribly obscure trivia at that. The only thing I want from this puzzle creator is MORE!
How much did Uber pay for 58A?
This is the first time I'm commenting to say I liked this. 90s and early 2000s movie trivia is fair game and the puzzle felt fair in general.

@CJ

Oh jeez, their 50th anniversary really dates me. It was very small potatoes at the beginning when it was on WTTW, our local PBS affiliate.
@CJ yes I  knew it as soon as I  saw  the clue as well. His review of North is legendary.  Anyhow, I loved Loved loved loved the theme of this crossword.

@CJ Someone not that familiar with Roger Ebert might see this puzzle and think he was just a curmudgeon. But of course, Ebert loved good movies, and was never hesitant to be heap praise on films that deserved it. 

I'm so grateful that IMDB features his reviews on countless films.

@Michael Weiland

I think there was a suspicion that Ebert got mellower in his later days.

His early reviews were relatively star-stingy compared to his later years.

That doesn't bother me a bit--I loved him in both phases just because he wrote so entertainingly.  He and I are in opposite corners on movies like "Blue Velvet", but I don't care.  I can't help but respect his viewpoint.

An old Irish tune known as ‚ÄúCockles and Mussels" or "Molly Malone‚Äù. Its first stanza is:

‚ÄúIn Dublin's fair city, where the girls are so pretty
I first set my eyes on sweet Molly Malone
As she wheeled her wheel-barrow
Through streets broad and narrow,
Crying, "Cockles and mussels, alive, alive, oh!"

Oh, oh, oh, Susannah
Don't you cry for me (oh Susannah, oh Susannah)
Cause I come from Alabama with my B-A-N-J-O on my knee
(Oh Susannah, oh Susannah)
______________
It's riddled with "Oh Susannahs" and lighthearted nonsense.  
e.g.

@Andrzej Something can be dumb ‚Äúblockbuster‚Äù fun, or it can be ‚Äúbrilliant‚Äù, but very few if any films are both. I daresay a Michael Bay film where Bruce Willis blows up a comet to save the planet is squarely in the former category‚Äîand a critic known for preferring artistry would be doing his audience a disservice if he were to hold back his negativity. You don‚Äôt need to agree with a movie critic for their critique to have value; you just need to understand their perspective and recognize where their review is coming from.

How is criticizing an action movie for it being siIIy anything else than unoriginal and unfunny? Of course they never make any sense, the acting is atrocious, and they usually run too long - basically, you could write any generic, grumpy thing about one and it would fit them all. And believe me, I know about grumpiness and how to use it! ü§£

It's all very low hanging fruit ü§∑üèΩ

I saw this film ten years ago when it was originally released, and I found it obno√óiou5Iy bad - its unforgiveable sin being the fact it is just a $t‚úìpid fantasy flick with a shallow story that wants the viewer to believe it is an intellectual masterpiece. The whole thing is ab5urdIy ¬ÆidicuIous, utterly reliant on special effects and cheap plot twists, and yet it desperately wants to be treated seriously. Another way to describe it would be as an exact opposite of a Monty Python movie, where you get some serious food for thought but expressed through siIIiness. In "Inception" you get pure siIIiness but with an annoyingly straight face.

@Andrzej

I think I might have predicted your reaction to "Inception"...

I think you have a keen eye for movies who take themselves too seriously, that are pretentious.

You can forgive full-on buffoonery, but you're looking for a very specific kind of profound, and if a movie misses by a fraction of a degree...

Either that or you just didn't think there was enough n*dity in "Inception".

@Andrzej
Clever ploy!
I never saw THAT movie, either.
Vast swaths of unseen flicks surround me, apparently.

@Francis

I guess you're right, to some extent, but maybe it's simpler - what I hate about "Inception", and Christopher Nolan movies in general, is how they are nothing more than action flicks but they try to make you believe they're profound. 

Also... I think action movie creators should have the guts to admit what they do is about entertainment, and entertainment only. Nolan seems to be implying a simple action movie is beneath him, so he tries to make his dreary spectacles about some profound message. üî© that I say.

I prefer anything profound to be served to me in writing. It is much more subtle then, unless it gets the Paulo Coelho treatment.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Just when I thought I couldn‚Äôt worship the woman more. 

I reread her often, you know? Especially when I get homesick, there is this passage:

‚ÄúThe desert, any desert, is indeed the valley of the shadow of death; come back from the desert and you feel like Alcestis, reborn. ‚Ä¶ [To fly across] is to miss the point. The point is to become disoriented, shriven, by the heat and the deceptive perspectives and the oppressive sense of carrion. The road shimmers. The eyes want to close.‚Äù

As I pick up from the store my undersized European (good grief! you call this a turkey?)  Thanksgiving turkey (for my husband to see to), her take on the Southwest she loved as much as I do becomes especially poignant.

@George. Sometimes things don't register properly. One day last week the time on my puzzle was correct, but what got posted to my stats was about half that.

For a streak only two days incorrect, I probably would not bother them with it, but you are correct that if your worked puzzles are showing 9 gold stars in a row, your streak should show that amount.
